title: 105_s2347
content: The Act may be cited as the Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act and aims to expand prevention efforts for methamphetamine abuse. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act aims to prevent methamphetamine abuse through school-based and community-based programs funded by grants from the Director of the Center for Substance Abuse Prevention. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act funds community-based prevention programs and school-based programs targeting districts with high rates of methamphetamine abuse. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act funds school-based and community-based prevention programs targeting high-risk populations for methamphetamine abuse, assists local government entities in prevention activities, and provides training for State and local officials. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act funds prevention activities, training for law enforcement officials, monitoring, and evaluation of prevention efforts. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act funds prevention activities, training for law enforcement officials, monitoring, and evaluation of prevention efforts, with priority given to areas experiencing high rates of methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Grants may also be used for targeted pilot programs to encourage innovation. The Comprehensive Methamphetamine Abuse Reduction Act allocates funds for prevention programs, evaluations, and dissemination of information on methamphetamine abuse. The Director is required to conduct analyses and submit annual reports to relevant committees in Congress. The Director must submit annual reports to specific Senate and House committees with the results of analyses and evaluations. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1999, with additional funding as needed for future years. SEC. 3. EXPANDING CRIMINAL PENALTIES AND LAW ENFORCEMENT FUNDING. The United States Sentencing Commission will create or amend federal sentencing guidelines for offenses related to the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine in violation of certain acts. The United States Sentencing Commission will adjust the base offense level for offenses related to the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine in violation of specific acts, increasing it by at least 3 offense levels above the current level. The base offense level for offenses related to the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine will be increased by at least 3 offense levels. If the offense created a substantial risk of danger to another person, the base offense level will be increased by not less than 6 offense levels. The base offense level for offenses related to the manufacture of amphetamine or methamphetamine will be increased by at least 3 offense levels, and if the offense created a substantial risk of danger to another person, the level will be raised by not less than 6 levels. The United States Sentencing Commission will promptly establish guidelines or amendments in response to this Act. The United States Sentencing Commission will promptly establish guidelines or amendments in response to this Act, with the amendments applying to offenses occurring 60 days after the enactment date. Increased resources are authorized for the Office of National Drug Control Policy to combat methamphetamine trafficking in designated high-intensity drug areas. Increased resources are authorized for the Office of National Drug Control Policy to combat methamphetamine trafficking in high-intensity drug areas, with $25,000,000 allocated for fiscal year 1999 and additional funding for fiscal years 2000 through 2004. SEC. 4. TREATMENT OF METHAMPHETAMINE ABUSE. Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for expanding treatment of methamphetamine abuse and addiction. The Director may make grants to public and non-profit entities for this purpose, with funds used for planning and administering treatment programs. Grants under Section 507 of the Public Health Service Act can be used for evidence-based programs, training health professionals in recognizing and treating methamphetamine abuse and addiction. Training in methamphetamine treatment methods for health professionals, planning, administration, and educational activities related to the treatment of methamphetamine abuse and addiction, monitoring and evaluation of treatment activities, and reporting information to health professionals and the public. The Director prioritizes grants for rural and urban areas with high rates of methamphetamine abuse. This includes monitoring treatment activities, pilot programs for innovation, and coordination with mental health services. The Director gives priority to rural and urban areas with high rates of methamphetamine abuse for grants. Up to $1,000,000 each fiscal year is allocated for analyses and evaluations of effective treatments and strategies for disseminating information on treatment services. The Director prioritizes rural and urban areas with high rates of methamphetamine abuse for grants. An annual report with analysis and evaluation results must be submitted to specific committees. $40,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1999, with additional funding for succeeding years. SEC. 5. EXPANDING METHAMPHETAMINE RESEARCH. Section 464N of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allow grants for interdisciplinary research on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including studying its effects on the human body and addictive nature. Research on the effects of methamphetamine abuse on the human body, addictive nature, connection to mental illness, prevention methods, treatment options, risk factors, and impact on pregnant women and fetuses. The Director shall disseminate research results on methamphetamine abuse and addiction, including pharmacological treatments, risk factors, effects on pregnant women and fetuses, and reasons for abuse or refraining from abuse. Authorization of appropriations for research is also provided.
